posts.html:
I'm an accomplished UX consultant, team leader and manager. I've been working for digital companies for 10+ years. I've progressed through the years as a designer, developer, and now I focus on User Experience.

I help businesses and teams understand the best UX practices and get the most out of their objectives. Working through problem-solving, concern management and user testing.

I've worked with many brands in my career and achieved results, delivered products and helped teams progress.

Right now I'm consulting for 101 Ways working with their client Springer Nature.

Portfolio Work

I have put together some Case Studies here which give an overview of some of my most recent placements and companies I've worked for.

I also have a pitch available on request, which outlines how I would structure processes, best practices and future directives to be used within any business or agency structure. Please email me at hello@kaiserbear.co.uk for that.

Over the years and recent engagements I've managed to make some videos and screen recordings of some of the work I've completed which can be viewed on my youtube channel here:

I've also decided to write a blog to capture my experiences and thoughts, to try and overcome that problem of conveying who I am, how I think to prospective new clients, encourage critique from peers in the industry and maybe also help others.

Questions you could ask me:

  • "What are your views on Jobs To Be Done?"
  • "How can we improve our design foundations and ways of working?"
  • "How does UX work within agile?"

Right now I'm consulting for 101 Ways [https://www.101ways.com/] working with

I also have a pitch available on request, which outlines how I would structure
processes, best practices and future directives to be used within any business
or agency structure. Please email me at hello@kaiserbear.co.uk for that. 

Over the years and recent engagements I've managed to make some videos and
screen recordings of some of the work I've completed which can be viewed on my
youtube channel here:

I've also decided to write a blog to capture my experiences and thoughts, to try
and overcome that problem of conveying who I am, how I think to prospective new
clients, encourage critique from peers in the industry and maybe also help
others. 

Questions you could ask me:

 * "What are your views on Jobs To Be Done?" 
 * "How can we improve our design foundations and ways of working?"
 * "How does UX work within agile?"

posts.html:
I started contracting back in 2010, I was 25 years of age and very new to the industry.

I began my professional career as a ‘web designer’. Very much a blag on my part, Adobe Photoshop was really all that I knew. I found myself being introduced to development and more specifically, developers.

Developers throughout my career have always been awkward, socially strange creatures. I was none of those. I was enthusiastic, creative, and always the joker in the pack. However, I was desperate to learn how to code. I didn’t want to have to rely on a developer to get my designs coded and released. I had been learning HTML, CSS and Javascript (more so jQuery) with my design work and had experienced clunky CMS tools like IBM’s websphere commerce. This to me was enough motivation to start looking for freelance work.

There were a couple of key developers in my early years who helped me learn and progress, they were good teachers. I was lucky to learn on the job, which is a common theme if you read on.

I’d been told by other designers and developers in my network that freelancing was a great opportunity, and more importantly — the money was amazing. What 25 year old wouldn’t grab that opportunity?

I was approached for a contract role as a ‘front end developer’. The money was good, I was extended a couple of times and I had to learn quickly on the job. A pressure I enjoyed.

Today

I’m now what I’d call a ‘seasoned’ contractor. I’ve experienced all the ups and downs that come from being a short term specialist. (Or what I call a ‘fixer’).

Let’s be clear, you become a specialist. For me contracting has been a journey of blagging less each time I take on a position.

I’ve migrated across fields of discipline, I’m now a UX consultant and I very much firmly believe in the core principles of delivering UX practises.

I haven’t hit a ceiling, I am progressing in every aspect of contracting. I’m still motivated to keep contracting after 10 years.

What I’ve learned

  • I have to accept the jobs that come, especially in the beginning you can’t be picky. This means taking on jobs that aren’t glamourous.
  • The reason you’re being hired, is because there’s a problem. You have to figure out very quickly what that problem is. It’s often people, or processes, or both. If not, you become the problem.
  • I have to accept that I could walk away from a project that could never complete, or get binned.
  • Take a break. Which means manage yourself, your time and more importantly — your company finances. In March 2018 I took a 5 day break to a hotel spa and did nothing except relax, eat and get massages. I’ve never returned from a trip so happy. Keep your mental health at a good level!
  • Get a good accountant. Soon you’ll be dealing with taxes, managing lump sums of cash and it’s wise to have someone who doesn’t dick you about. Even better if they can ring you and call you a dick! Make sure those bills get paid, the stress isn’t worth it.
  • Be a good negotiator. You have to get good at dealing with agents, job boards and the bullshit that comes with it. I’ve been lucky to have a close relative who works on the other side of the fence. If you’re being sent across at £300 a day, the agent is asking for £400. If you’re direct with a client or agency, those skills need to be further multiplied as actually agents cover your ass when you’re chasing invoices.
  • Find a way of maintaining a portfolio that’s not a constant ball ache. I’ve had many versions of my portfolio up over the years — as soon as you’ve done a job for 3/6 months it becomes drastically out of date in every way. Keep it simple.
  • If you’re looking for work, upload the CV onto the job boards. It will alert all the ‘good’ agents that you’re on the market even if you’re not connected with them on LinkedIn.
  • Be a nice person. Might sound ridiculous, but I’ve always made sure bridges are left standing after leaving a job. I’ve returned to multiple companies over the years because I’ve been someone they’ve remembered. The value there might not even be the output of my work, but my ability to collaborate and get along with people.

Looking to switch?

If you’re that person currently faced with the prospect of going freelancing:

  • Yes, you don’t get paid if you’re sick or need a holiday. Get good with your money. If you’re that person (which I have been) that thinks “Ah man I’m losing so much money if I’m not in work…” then you’re a dick with money. Get better.
  • If you’re hell bent on the ‘cause’ and wanting to be working on pixel perfect projects. Wicked, go work for Facebook and earn £35k a year. If you don’t like pressure, then contracting isn’t for you.
  • "What if I’m out of work or can’t find anything?" Know your market. If you’re in a role which isn’t sought after, then you need to start making goals to ensure that you are. Right now, there’s a lack of UX experts who have worked as a designer, and a developer. Engineer your own USP, don’t rest on what you have.
  • It’s a lifestyle. You’ll work weird hours sometimes, other times you’ll be Dolly Parton. Get used to it.
  • You’re a superstar. If you’re constantly hitting walls with your learning, people and processes — then be a freelancer. You can migrate to a consultant and be paid to inform businesses on what they need to do. That’s the dream right?

posts.html:
This is some work I did for a client back in 2019 on the uses of Figma and working around concepts of a design system. Very much out of the remit of my usual UX work however, there were teams at this particular client who were still focussing on using tools like Photoshop and InDesign when building web assets.

As you can see here Ive built the client a simple wireframe and demo of a mobile navigation and working through various solutions. I also did some work to highlight the benefits of using components and a component library within Figma.

highlight the benefits of using components and a component library within Figma.

posts.html:
Having an understanding of coding principles is going to benefit you as a UX thinker.

I practised as a 'front end developer' for a few years. My natural yearning to translate my designs to rendered interactive applications was insatiable. That for me, was going to save me time and effort. I could validate my assumptions, with data-less working screens.

HTML, CSS and Javascript (The big 3) I think it is fundamental learning for anyone working in a product/tech environment. How much you know, or how deep you wish to dive into the world of coding is relative to your needs.

Why?

The benefits of understanding the client (browser) languages are numerous:

  • Improved output: from inception, solutions and ideas can be curated and critiqued with a view of the future velocity of your team, and business.
  • Improve your communication and connection with developers. You'll produce better ideas and solutions if you can challenge limitations and capabilities in software.
  • Don't be limited by what software can give you for prototyping.
  • Presenting a browser or mobile-based application to your peers and have them available to test with users, for me, surpasses the limitations you have with relying on software tools.

How?

  • Take an online course. https://www.udemy.com/course/the-web-developer-bootcamp/ is an excellent introduction into not only client-side but also server-side development and front end practises. Learn with the videos and complete the examples, you'll end up with something you can tweak yourself and use to your advantages in professional environments.
  • Speak to developers and show them your prototype. It's essential to emphasise you're not impeding or even contributing to production or pipelines. Ask for advice and talk them through what you're studying.
  • Persistence! Developing or writing code for me never felt a natural process. I found that a simple web page or design app to start and setting goals helped.

Codepen is another great resource.

I'd like to extend a 'thank you' to a friend called Reuben, who gave me a tip about the Udemy developer course. I'm still using what I've learned from that course today.

Do I have to do this to become a good 'UX pro'?

Absolutely not. We are all different when it comes to practising UX methods and techniques in order to further digital products. Will it give you a competitive advantage? Yes.

So, if you find yourself knocking up some wireframes or re-writing some user journeys, think about how you could present those in a browser, clickable and testable.

posts.html:
I'm currently at a client site with Zoopla. For purposes of highlighting what I'm doing and for some portfolio work - here's an example of some white-boarding that I've completed with a product manager.

Some context

I've been working on a social media product, and over a few weeks I've been conducting workshops and research on identifying user types, generating empathy maps and problem statements.

We're now focussing on some data with regards to a specific step in the product and user journey that we can improve, quickly. Watch the video to see more.

The next task for me would be to visually realise what we've decided to do here, into some low fidelity wireframes for simulation.

Hopefully this shows how I work and how collaboration with ideas leads to design iteration and testing.

With respect of my client, this is as much detail as I could share, but hopefully still gives you as the audience of this article, and insight into ways of working and UX methods.

I'm a big fan of using technology to illustrate ideas, and connect lines between documentation and visual aides. You can't beat a white board when collaborating with team members.

posts.html:
What is IR35?

IR35 isn't a new thing. HMRC devised the legislation in 1999, a very complex and grey set of rules. The aim is to stop individuals from working as recognised employees of a company, but who instead set themselves up as limited companies. In industries such as banking, it's widely known that contractors earning a high day rate have sat on those jobs for years and years.

Therefore, in the eyes of HMRC and the government - these workers are paying fewer taxes.

So why is there such hype at the moment?

From the 6th of April, private companies and corporations will now be liable. What this means is that many are not prepared. According to HMRC, the changes will bring an extra £3.1bn in additional tax revenues between 2020 and 2024. [1] The public sector have been making decisions on IR35 workers since 2017.

I have spoken to many people in my professional working circle. The ambiguity is driving fear amongst businesses, recruiters and freelancers.

The permanent market is rocketing.

An ex-colleague of mine recently decided to 'take the plunge' and set herself up as a contractor. I was of-course encouraging and advised her of great benefits and steep learning curves of being a contractor. Her feedback: the contracting market is scarce! She may now have to reconsider her decision and stay working in a permanent capacity.

Are you in or out?

So you'll see now on places like LinkedIn, recruiters advertising roles with caveats:

"Inside IR35."

"This role is outside of IR35."

"Inside" is the one to consider. You will be liable to pay full employee tax. (Even though, you won't receive any further benefits an employee would gain, i.e. holiday, sick leave etc.)

"How can I prove that I'm not eligible for IR35 and I'm operating as a consultant/contractor?"

Statement of work

Have your deliverables clearly defined and measurable. If you're there to fulfil specific requirements, then push to have those included in your agreement.

If you are receiving any employee benefits in kind - this could be a free breakfast - through to being trained. It's all flags that you're working as an employee of their business, not a contractor of "your-business ltd".

Length of contract

If you're being offered a role for 12+ months - then that should be a concern for your private sector company. Quite frankly, in my opinion, that should also be a concern for your personal development.

Right to substitution

"If I'm sick, someone else can replace me."

This conversation was always a topic that I've discussed with other contractors over the years.

As a contractor, you technically work for your limited company. The contract that you sign is between the private/public ltd and your private ltd. So in theory, if your ltd company could send a replacement - then that would null and void any further conversation about IR35.

I have never engaged with this method, and I would encourage you not to either - it's avoidance no matter how you look at it. (This is my opinion, you make up your mind).

Update 08/03/2020

A recent tribunal involving a man name Robert Lee, a contractor at Nationwide Bank from 2007 to 2014 - has awarded HMRC with the case brought before them.

Mr Lee's two main arguments in this tribunal:

  • He didn't have control over his day to day work
  • He provided a right to substitution
"The right to substitution was fettered with Nationwide having the final decision and effectively a right to veto. Nationwide wanted Mr Lee and in reality, would not accept a replacement. The contract was therefore one of personal service."

Design market fluctuation

There are many reasons why there are fluctuations in design job appreciation. I could write another article entirely on the perception of design in the digital industry. The uncertainty around IR35, in my opinion, is causing further gaps. With more and more people applying for permanent roles, £30-80k differences in some instances, it's hitting the market and confidence of highly skilled designers.

Where's this going?

I'm 100% not an expert in any of this. But I'll give you my "ten cents."

What I do know is that this is having a significant effect on the jobs market for designers. Not just designers, it's affecting everyone connected. Let's help each other understand the further implications and educate where we can.

My view here is that this will drive opportunities away from those at the beginning of their careers. Progression of digital best practises and new technologies will also slow down because of a saturated and stagnated marketplace.

I don't think it will stay this way. Some will fall; some businesses will be example cases. That's inevitable. A year from now, it will be interesting to see how the market prevails.

The world is changing."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Past & Future"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Right now, I find myself at a junction. posts.html:
I've tried my very best up unto this point to avoid writing anything on the subject of Coronavirus.

Globally this pandemic has had an overwhelming effect on people's lives. I am very thankful for being safe and healthy. More so, I have empathy for those who have suffered a loss. The world is changing.

Past & Future

Right now, I find myself at a junction. I'm sure many people have reached this phase in their careers, the feeling that I have is that I need something more. I've spent the last 10+ years of my career working across multiple disciplines, I've adapted with the opportunities that have come my way. Before this years period began, I was already considering what I wanted for the future of my career.

I've worked as a freelancer/contractor for some time. I have faced many challenges in my career so far. However, I need more than that.

As a consultant, there are many considerations and hurdles to overcome. Often the building you are walking into is 'burning'.

I'll be honest, I've been good at that, and I've made many mistakes. In many respects having to adapt quickly and gain the trust of client employees and being embedded into teams - I've enjoyed immensely. I've made many great friends along the way, and my skill set has dramatically benefited from regular and frequent 'hops' to new adventures.

Where it's been bad, I've ended up with a familiar feeling of leaving a product cycle or 'project' as incomplete. Worse, I've been moved about and tasked with various requirements - usually due to a company going through 'transformation'.

I believe the reason I've acquired previously is to help immediate and pressing issues with that company. I've never been there to integrate long term. What I've never enjoyed is having to leave like Mary Poppins without a fancy umbrella.

I want to be able to progress my career now and commit my short to mid-term future with a business/product/service - and achieve goals.

Present

Currently, I'm out of work, as I can imagine a lot of people are. But I'm excited. Things will get back on their feet with the economy; however challenging that may be - and what will come with that is opportunities.

I think for the first time in my life, I'm ready to wait and seek out something that could be amazing. I've been doing some odd bits of freelance in my downtime - that's been fun. Coding again (very lightly and not to be looked at) which has been refreshing. It's reminded me about the beauty of smaller projects and delivering.

Thank you if you have read this far. I try and update this portal with work, information but also my thoughts.

posts.html:
Here are some recent examples of projects and work that I have undertaken.

Problem

Internal teams couldn't adapt web pages to be responsive in their delivery using existing technology. 65% of users couldn't see these pages correctly on their mobile phones. Internal teams were spending 100's hours trying to navigate the restrictions in their technology.

Solution

Adapted an existing tool they had and built/managed a bespoke team of 15 designers and developers. Delivered the project within eight weeks, 4 weeks early. Educated internal marketing and creative teams in how to use the new functionality, reducing weight on the support teams at Arcadia.

Problem:

Swedbank was looking to reduce customer service calls and requests that they were receiving around how to manage their user entitlements for large corporate accounts. No solution existed.

Solution:

From business requirements, the early and initial assumptions were largely disproved by producing wireframes and testing them with users. Significantly reduced the resource time allocated to the product and released sooner than anticipated by delivering a more straightforward and user-focussed product.

Problem:

Estate agents often receive leads with low value/quality ratings and have to spend lots of time qualifying that lead. They also have no real way of managing their day to day effectively in one tool.

Solution:

Designed a mobile-first solution with wireframes, and ensured early testing with clients. This proved/disproved over 100 different hypotheses quickly.  This leads to major elements/behaviours of the product to be refined as a result, saving time and overheads.

Problem:

Argos in 2021 is moving to a paperless solution for their catalogue. The problem in Ireland is that in-store tablets don't exist at present. The infrastructure isn't present as it is in the UK.

Solution:

Converted the existing website and user journeys to be adapted for tablet/touch use in-store. Allowing customers to reserver multiple items in-store and removing any need for use of the physical catalogue.

posts.html:
There are many studies to suggest that investing in UX is vital to business growth. That’s why the world’s biggest brands such as Spotify, Netflix, Zoom, Google Hangouts, Microsoft Teams - are championing UX.


How does UX 'fit' into our team?

As a consultant I implement the following methods and ways of working if they don't already exist:

  • User Personas
  • Problem Statements
  • User Testing
  • Wire framing
  • Prototyping

We take the knowledge we have as a business, and we set about to prove/disprove our hypothesis via problem statements. The scope for most online businesses falls under 3 categories. Acquisition, Conversion and Retention. These are the three core areas in which UX can improve learning, profits and reduce time/effort.

posts.html:
As a consultant I often find myself working alone, or engaging other teams who don't have their own design faculties available.

During times when working from home is more prevalent and required by clients, it's become far more challenging to conduct user testing virtually.

It's well documented the companies that provide these services in variation, but at a cost. (Screen recorders, all the way up to booking physical human tests).

If you're taking a qualitative approach in whatever round of testing you're conducting, it is possible to get some value by using tools that you could already be paying for.

Manage your time

Firstly, managing your time and allowing users to book appointments is going to be fundamental, I'd recommend Calendly.

You can cancel your subscription by month, should your focus on testing need a pause for e.g. This also allows for you to instantly book meetings with... Zoom.

Remote session via Zoom/Google Hangouts

The next is to utilise a web meeting tool such as Zoom or Google Hangouts. That way you can enable your candidate to share their screen with you, which is vital when you want to test something the user can physically access. That could be a link that you send them, i.e. a Figma link or a web URL.

Record the session

This is where having a decent hardware set up is necessary, but the next thing I then do is record the session via something like Quicktime or OBS studio. Be sure to capture the correct audio inputs and displays when doing so.

What you end up with is a chunky file size (probably 500mb per 10 minutes depending on your frame rate, etc) which you can export, and convert to mp4 (use VLC player if you ever need to convert formats).

I have conducted at least 10 sessions like this recently. Make sure you always perform a recorded test before you go into your 'live' session.

If you have any feedback on this, or have advice on other tools, please drop me an email.
